If beauty and innocence please,</br>With sense and sincerity join'd,</br>Columbia was mistress of these,</br>For goodness still glow'd in her mind.
The blush of the joy-giving day</br>Had nothing more sweet to the view,</br>Nor the flow'rets which brighten in May</br>Could boast of a lovelier hue.
Like Dian she haunted the groves,</br>Or sat by the side of the stream,</br>Attended by graces and loves,</br>Columbia was ev'ry one's dream.
Young Ivor pursu'd the fleet prey,</br>The wood-land re-echoes aloud,</br>The fair-one he views in his way,</br>He leaves the dull sport and the crowd.
His cheeks were both ruddy and fair,</br>His stature was comely and tall,</br>As black as the jet was his hair,</br>And a manliness dignify'd all.
He view'd the young virgin with joy!</br>A rapture he ne'er felt before,</br>For Cupid, the heart-wounding boy,</br>In love now had fix'd him secure.
He sigh'd and approach'd the bright maid,</br>Yet his passion his tongue could not tell,</br>But she found, from the little he said</br>She lov'd him, alas!  but too well.
To the cottage she hasted hard-by,</br>Where dwelt her fond parent, Content,</br>Columbia, the joy of his eye,</br>Was the blessing kind Nature had sent.
In her he fix'd all the delight</br>Which mortals can taste here below,</br>She cheer'd him from morning to night,</br>At distance kept sorrow and woe.
For innocence still has such pow'r,</br>It adds to each blessing we share,</br>It brightens the dark dreary hour,</br>For virtue's not known to despair.
Lorenzo, the name of her sire,</br>Had experienc'd the turnings of fate,</br>Now humble, he wou'd not aspire,</br>As he knew what it was to be great;
That Fortune was fickle and blind,</br>So made himself blest with his lot,</br>Yet still he allow'd she was kind,</br>While she gave him his daughter and cot.
The youth sought the happy retreat,</br>His modesty spoke in his praise,</br>He had not the face of deceit,</br>And Honour was fond of his ways.
Lorenzo his passion approves,</br>How happy the nymph and the youth!</br>How pure and how sweet were their loves,</br>Inspir'd by honour and truth.
Each morning brings joy and delight,</br>And all the long day is the same,</br>But ah!  the soft parting at night,</br>Gave rapture too tender to name.
Yet the moments seem'd slowly to glide,</br>'Till Hymen his altar prepare,</br>To make bright Columbia a bride,</br>And bless both the youth and the fair.
Ye lovers, attend to the tale,</br>And drop the sad tribute to woe,</br>It must o'er the hardest prevail,</br>And the tear of compassion bid flow.
Loud clamours are heard from afar,</br>America rings with alarms,</br>The trumpet sounds loudly to war,</br>And echo repeats it — to arms.
Columbia was deck'd for the day,</br>How blooming, how mild, and how sweet,</br>The rites of chaste Hymen but stay</br>To render their raptures compleat:
When hark!  how discordant the sound,</br>The war-whoop is heard on the plain,</br>The Indians the cottage surround,</br>And innocence pleads all in vain.
The savages seize her soft hair,</br>The murdering tomahawk flies,</br>Her accents pierce through the vast air,</br>But in vain are, alas!  all her cries.
They heed not the honours of age,</br>But murder the trembling sire,</br>And the cottage of peace, in their rage,</br>Irrev'rent is now set on fire.
Fond Ivor the tragedy views,</br>Sad prospect to virtue and love!</br>The corpse of Columbia bedews</br>With tears, which his passion must prove.
Yet the murderers, savagely kind,</br>Put an end to his pain and his grief,</br>The streams from each heart they have join'd,</br>For death gave the lover relief.
Ye nymphs of Britannia, rejoice,</br>No war-whoop is heard o'er your plains,</br>But safely you tune the soft voice,</br>Or listen to innocent strains.
Yet while you're thus happy and free,</br>For America lift a fond pray'r,</br>That soon they such blessings may see,</br>And peace put an end to the war;
That brotherly friendship and love</br>In concord again may unite,</br>And the bond of alliance improve,</br>To give to each party delight.
Ye patriots, exert all your skill,</br>May your eloquence meet with success,</br>Then slaughter no longer shall kill,</br>Nor discord the nation depress.
The olive all flourishing fair,</br>Its shade, all delighting, shall spread,</br>And the heroes who conquer and spare,</br>Find the laurels encircle their head.
Rich Commerce again shall expand,</br>All happy her sails be unfurl'd,</br>Mirth and plenty shall smile o'er the land,</br>And Britain be fam'd thro' the world.</br>
